data.title: TSX intellisense does not initially show suggestions for properties when the tag is a dotted reference
Select for Compare disables context menu in OPEN EDITORS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14 Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10, macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open two files in the OPEN EDITORS section
2. Right click on one and choose Select for Compare
3. Now select another file in OPEN EDITORS and right click to try to bring up context menu

No content menu
This is a regression in 1.14, it doesn't repro in 1.13. Perhaps due to recent work on the Diff view for accessibility?

data.title: Update Promise definition
data.body: As a follow up to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30216#issuecomment-313558951, this updates the definition of Promise in winjs.base.d.ts to use type parameter defaults and addresses errors in several files where either TypeScript could not pick the correct type or where the code using the promise was trying to force the wrong type (e.g. trying to explicitly force a `TPromise<Something>` into a `TPromise<void>`).

data.title: Enhancement: 'html.format.wrapAttributes' -> Add exceptions
data.body:
Just an improvement to the new html.format.wrapAttributes setting: 

Could it be possible to add an exception list to this? Like for 'html.format.unformatted' ?

Use case: 
I'm using Polymer and every html file I write must begin with a series of <link rel="import" href="...">. I'd like to use the wrap attributes format as 'force-aligned' everywhere else but there, otherwise my imports section becomes twice as long for nothing.

data.title: Files in node_modules show up in search despite being excluded
data.body:
I have an exclusion in `files.exclude` for `**/node_modules` but files there still show up in search results:

![Search](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1078012/27974113-6796963e-6354-11e7-9170-a9d8721ec413.png)

I tried copying the `files.exclude` section and naming it `search.exclude` but it made no difference (the comment says `search.exclude` inherits `files.exclude` so I didn't really expect that to fix it).

data.title: When already open `--wait` forces you to close all windows.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a directory `code ~/src/somedir`
2. Open a file with `code ~/src/otherdir/somefile --wait`

There doesn't seem to be a way to close just the wait window and have that return without closing vscode out completely.

It would be nice to be able to use this as my git editor/difftool, but can't do that with how it currently works.  I would expect that closing the only tab, or the CMD+Q would exit the current editor in the waiting state, not have to close down code completely.

data.title: Refresh explorer should keep focus on a selected folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

__Steps to Reproduce:__

1. Open a file (preview or permanent)
2. Focus any folder
3. Refresh the explorer & focus will return to the file

__Reproduces without extensions:__ Yes

Usually this doesn't present as an issue, whether due to the project being small, folders being on the same visual plane as the resource, personal preference as to the appropriateness (general or specific) of the context switch, or any other given reason.

However, this _almost always_ presents as a problem when navigating e.g. `node_modules`, where the folder structure is flattened & lengthy enough to make re-finding your resource more of a pain than it would normally. The workaround is simple - explicitly select a file before you refresh - but in my experience it's easy to forget this and waste time going back to your resource, due to a refresh usually being needed because of some external change to the folder structure that has nothing to do with vscode.

I'm not aware if there are any pre-existing limitations, either due to architecture or design, and scanning the issues did not reveal any existing effort toward this issue (apologies if I missed something!)

Thanks for your time! 😄

data.title: TS Version Selector for Multiroot Workspaces
data.body:
# Question
How should the TS version work in multi root workspaces?

You can currently select between the workspace version of TS or from the bundled / global version. In the multiroot world, we plan on only starting a single TSserver instance but what version options should be shown in these cases


# Startup Scenarios

1. Two+ workspaces with no tsdk settings

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - Bundled TS version

1. Two+ workspaces with user tsdk  settings that points to an absolute path

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - TS at the absolute path from the tsdk

1. Two+ workspaces with user tsdk settings that points to a relative path

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - For each workspace, check if the tsdk can be resolved relative to the workspace. Include in suggestions if it does. Filter out duplicate TS versions. Pick first as default.

1. Two+ workspaces where one has a tsdk setting in the workspace settings

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - Bundled TS version (default)
        - Version from tsdk from the workspace

1. Two+ workspaces where multiple workspaces have tsdk settings in their workspace settings

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - Bundled TS version (default)
        - For each workspace, check if the tsdk can be resolved relative to that workspace. Include in suggestions if it does. Filter out duplicate TS versions

1. Two+ workspaces where one or more workspaces have tsdk settings in their workspace settings and the user has an absolute path tsdk setting

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - TSDK from  absolute user path (default)
        - For each workspace, check if the tsdk can be resolved relative to that workspace. Include in suggestions if it does. Filter out duplicate TS versions

1. Two+ workspaces where one or more workspaces have tsdk settings in their workspace settings and the user has relative path tsdk setting

    **Proposed Version Suggestions:**
        - For each workspace, check both the workspace tsdk and the user tsdk. Include these in suggestions if they can be resolved. Filter out duplicate TS versions. Pick first version from the user tsdk setting as the default.

data.title: Debugging: Add support for annotating stack frames with icons

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We should add support for annotating stack frames with icons to enable debugger authors to provide more metadata for a given stack frame.

**Example:** The stack frame is within EmberJS code, therefore a EmberJS icon is shown next to it.

![27021463-fb856e3c-4f37-11e7-9012-dfe09645339b](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/173559/27970927-9460b0a4-6305-11e7-91e2-03164a64feaa.png)

**Value prop:**
More metadata for a a given stack frames helps developers understand the context and by highlighting library code we can help developers to navigate their code faster.

This feature is inspired by Mozilla's Debugger.html project: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3154

**Steps:**
- Extend stack frame view to render icon if available
- Extend Debugger protocol?
- Prototype library detection in vscode-node-debug or vscode-chrome-debug

Ping @roblourens, @weinand

data.title: Test plan item for prettier diffs
data.body:
Testing #30087 

Complexity: 2

- [x] any platform - **@sandy081**

Please look at some diffs like the ones presented in #30087 or #23636 .

Two things changed:

* we do some post processing on the LCS result to present a more pleasant diff. This involves shifting diffs down (leads to better merge changes of adjacent diffs) and then shifting diffs back up (to align with empty lines or whitespace only lines).

* diffing when trim whitespace is not ignored has changed substantially, i.e. lines are now diffed with trim whitespace ignored and then equal lines (with trim whitespace ignored) get diffed w.r.t. trim whitespace on a secondary pass.

To test, simply open some diffs and check if they represent better or worse the actual file edit.


---

Release Notes contribution (someone needs to paste this in to 1.15.md which doesn't exist yet):

With this release, we have made some tweaks to our diff algorithm to adjust the differences (which are found with the help of a Longest-Common-Substring algorithm) in such a way that they are more pleasing to the human eye.

In some cases, this means we will be more aligned with the output of `git diff` (which also incorporates some of these heuristics), but in other cases (like when only trim whitespace has changed), our result will no longer contain the LCS, so it will be different than `git diff`, but in our opinion it will also be more pleasing. 

> you can use a screenshot like in #23636 , just show a screenshot of `git diff` vs us in the case of indenting the code as in #23636

data.title: npm test breaks vs code extension tests
data.body:
NOTE: This issue occurs on Ubuntu as well.

[The documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/testing-extensions) states that npm test has been modified for VS Code. npm test has been modified to (1) download and unzip VS Code, (2) launch the extension tests inside VS Code, and (3) print the results to the console along with an exit code to designate success or failure.

The problem is that when the zip file is downloaded and unzipped, the folder that the version of VS Code is in is not expected by the tests that are run in step (2). The attached image demonstrates this issue.

![vscodeissue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28878539/27965983-78af71d2-62f2-11e7-8563-f26c8ce7af1a.PNG)

- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.7|
|tslint|eg2|0.16.0|


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make sure that the .vscode-test folder has been deleted (or never created). Such as when you clone the repository.
2. npm install
3. npm run vscode:prepublish
4. npm test --silent (also occurs when dropping --silent)

data.title: Move our watermark to resources so that distro can pick it up
Improve activity bar overflow logic
data.body:
**Current**

The current behavior of the activity bar only shows the overflow item when at least one entire option is obscured. This means it is possible for an option to be 99% obscured and no way to select it.

![dotdotdot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/27720822-667bb7dc-5d5c-11e7-943a-b78e6717c92d.gif)

**Expected**

As soon as an item is a non-zero amount of obscured, it should disappear, and the previous item should become the overflow item `...`.

data.title: Add right-click menu to files in Search and Call Stack file listings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1 (1.13.1)
- OS Version: OS X 10.10.5

Both the Search Results and the Debug/Call Stack panes include listings of the found/involved files. However, I often finding myself wondering where the heck one of the listed files is. Is it in my code? Is it something in Node? Is it in an extension? The only way I've found is to open the file and then right-click on the file header, choosing "Reveal in Sidebar". It took me a while to find this (months, really), and is more indirect than it needs to be.

Feature request: add a right-click menu to each file name in the Search Results and Debug/Call Stack file listings. The menu would include everything relevant from the right-click menu on open file headers, which currently includes:

- Copy Path
- Reveal in Finder
- Reveal in Sidebar

Even better would be a way to view the path in situ, without having to switch contexts. Perhaps there could be a disabled "Path" menu item which shows the file path, or a hierarchical "Show Path" menu whose contents is just the file path (disabled). This could be added both to the file listings and to the current file header menu.

data.title: Add ability to rename terminals
data.body: It would be great to be able to change the name displayed in the terminals dropdown for each terminal. This is a pretty common situation for me (which `bash` was the right one?): It would be nice to have an `edit` button next to this select element, even a plain input reachable via an entry in the command palette would do it. I believe it's possible to do this using the API, but I think it would be better to also have a more easily accessible option at hand. What do you think?

data.title: Search panel -- annoying "toggle replace button"
data.body: The "toggle replace button" (inside the yellow rectangle in the screenshot below) is broken in so many ways, let me enumerate them: 1. It's whole purpose, I guess, is to hide a rarely used input in order to barely show a couple more lines of results. But why even hiding the "replace" input? I don't know about you but I've never found a use for the "files excluded through settings" input, it's not even editable, why not hiding it instead? maybe "files to exclude" as well? It seems like a more logic approach to me. 2. We are wasting a whole bunch of pixels (in the red rectangle below) just because of it. 3. Even if you open it, you'll probably find it closed anyway pretty soon. Just switch to another panel and come back to the search panel, it's closed again. I can't even count how many time I wrote inside the "files to include" input by mistake. 4. It can't be opened with the keyboard, it needs to be clicked. Do you want to check the explorer or git while using it? Sorry, click it again. The best solution to me is getting rid of it all together, but I guess a reasonable solution is to add the ability to hide it via a `search.alwaysOnInputs` setting or something. I wouldn't mind an analogous setting for the floating search widget. What do you think?

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Fedora 25

Steps to Reproduce:

1. wget http://norvig.com/big.txt
2. gedit big.txt
3. select all text and copy
4. create a new file in vscode and paste

The copied text is truncated. Note: gedit prints a message on console:
```
(gedit:665): Gdk-WARNING **: Error writing selection data: Error writing to file descriptor: Broken pipe
```

Reproduces without extensions: Yes.

The behavior also occurs when copying from a terminal into vscode. When copying from chrome into vscode, the content is not truncated.

data.title: How can a Code Action insert text that contains replacement placeholders/tabstops?
data.body:
I'm familiar with snippets/completions being able to include tokens that the user can tab-between, however I'm struggling to find if it's possible to do something similar with a code action.

For example, this code action allows you to wrap a widget around some selected code:

![Wrap in new widget](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1078012/27956016-a1629560-630f-11e7-9101-04d7b6c14457.png)

The word `widget` is intended to be replaced by the user with the name of the class that they're wrapping this with.

Currently my code action executes a command which calls `vs.workspace.applyEdit`, however it doesn't look like `WorkspaceEdit` has support for placeholders like this.

Is there another way I can handle this? Eg. can I somehow get Code to do a replacement that can contain tokens/placeholders?

data.title: Test plan item for large files
data.body:
Test plan item for #30180:

- [x] 32 bit installation - **@michelkaporin**
- [x] 64 bit installation - **@sandy081**

fyi @egamma 

> Note to testers: I am not really interested in various ways that you can cause an OOM crash :)

Files will be considered large if they are above 30MB or above 300K lines. Such large files will never get tokenization, wrapping, indent guides, nor folding. Also, they will not travel to the extension host, nor to the web worker, so no diffing, quick diffing, link detection or word based suggestions. <-- parts of this is new

Otherwise, files that are larger than 5MB do not travel to the extension host, but otherwise use the regular file path (i.e. have tokenization, wrapping, etc. etc.) <-- this is not new.

* **Please do a smoke test of what working with a large file feels like**.
* does editing work ok, pasting, enter, etc.
* does find in file work, etc.

Notes:
* I have successfully opened a 1.3 GB file with 1.5 MM lines or a 351 MB file with 6.3 MM lines and I was able to work with it (except saving/hot exit)
* our memory usage is mostly driven by file size + 2 objects allocated per line (one being the actual string of the line) + an array of pointers to those line objects.
* try to find some of the limitations / steps that should work without additional memory consumption that end up leading to a crash (i.e. are there features that end up doing massive memory allocation when they should not?).
* is at a minimum the "read-only" experience OK ? (the scenario is mostly log files)

---

Release Notes contribution (someone needs to paste this in to 1.15.md which doesn't exist yet):

Large files are always a great way to stress-test an editor. We currently use a line based representation of the text buffer, which has some serious advantages, but also disadvantages, especially in terms of memory consumption (e.g. a file with very many short lines).

Any file that is over 30MB or over 300K lines will be considered a large file and handled in certain code paths, specially. By choosing to disable certain features for such files, e.g. tokenization, line guides, wrapping or folding, we were able to optimize the memory usage, in some cases, by as much as 50%.

Additionally, large files will never travel to our web worker, which computes diff information, link detection, or word based completions. This helps in reducing the memory pressure on the OS.

Some of the optimizations will impact all files, although the effects will be hard to notice with small files. We have decided to lift the hard coded file size limit of 50MB on 64-bit installations and enforce a 300MB file size limit of 32-bit installations.

---

Emergency toggles:
* [`MAX_FILE_ZIE`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/c5bf26a627a5641e0b0a76e8a0b9a6b56be9d434/src/vs/platform/files/common/files.ts#L527)
* [`USE_MIMINAL_MODEL_LINE`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/dbbc064c1368bfec65a1611590a2a366d5cac61c/src/vs/editor/common/model/textModel.ts#L22) - uses a different implementation for `ModelLine` that does not have properties for all of the tokenization state and has a lazy markers property.
* [`USE_IDENTITY_LINES_COLLECTION`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/dbbc064c1368bfec65a1611590a2a366d5cac61c/src/vs/editor/common/viewModel/viewModelImpl.ts#L24) - uses a different implementation for the ViewModel line mapping that prohibits wrapping and folding from working and assumes a 1:1 mapping.
* [`AVOID_SLICED_STRINGS `](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/dbbc064c1368bfec65a1611590a2a366d5cac61c/src/vs/workbench/services/textfile/electron-browser/modelBuilder.ts#L14) - takes the strings that make up lines and runs them through a nodejs Buffer to avoid having a `(sliced string)` per line.
* Additionally, all the commits that touched something w.r.t. memory improvements contain "#30180" in their message so if something horrible happens, git bisect on those commits should uncover it.

data.title: Add API to open a file or diff editor on a specific selection range (fixes #30241)
